awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics:   Performance based commitment devices and academic success
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation centers on a novel mechanism that acts as both a commitment device and an incentive instrument for college students to improve their academic performance. 

The proposal is at the intersection of research in behavioral economics and education where there is a growing interest in the insights that one field can bring into  the other. The proposal uses mixed methods - field and lab experiments - to explore a creative mechanism to improve academic performance. The evaluation is performed through randomized experiments designed to accomplish a set of goals, namely: (1) draw stronger inferences on the effectiveness of the proposed mechanism; (2) predict selection into a successful path of studies as a function of preferences and beliefs; (3) identify the importance of commitment and loss aversion for participants. The proposal will contribute to the study of a number of direct questions addressing the impact of incentives on commitment, and the link between preferences and self-selection into such a program.

The stagnation of US college completion rates over the past 20 years has been particular surprising given increases in overall college attendance and returns to college education. A natural question to ask is what factors determine the likelihood of a student's success in college, conditional on entering. Little research has been done to help identify programs that could help battle problems of present bias. This dissertation not only introduces a mechanisms that boosts student performance by helping them  commit to academic goals, but will also help to shape the knowledge of how different behaviorally-inspired incentive schemes can be utilized to boost student performance in general.

por.por_cntn:
Researchers and policymakers are increasingly interested in designing monetary incentive programs to improve student outcomes. The motivation for introducing these interventions is straightforward: Students may be investing too little effort into their education, perhaps because students have time-inconsistent preferences and the returns to an education are not realized until the long run. Insufficient effort consequently affects student performance in courses, graduation prospects, and labor market outcomes. By offering a monetary incentive, students can receive an immediate return for increasing their effort. Despite the vastness and popularity of monetary incentive programs, the findings from prior studies are quite disheartening.

While monetary incentive programs in education have largely been ineffective and very costly to implement, studies from other domains, such as savings, weight loss, and smoking cessation, have investigated the promise of the commitment device. Contrary to a monetary reward, with a commitment device, an agent voluntarily signs a contract agreeing to incur a monetary punishment for failing to meet a future requirement. Researchers have studied the commitment device primarily as a means to help present-biased, procrastinating agents restrict future choice sets by making “sub-optimal” deviations more costly. In higher education, studies suggest that student procrastination is prominent, growing, and significantly correlated with academic shortcomings. Despite this, no research to date has examined the efficacy of allowing students the opportunity to commit to a monetary punishment for failing to meet an academic performance target.

This project, thanks to the funding from the National Science Foundation, investigates the role of commitment and motivation in education by evaluating a program that acts as both a commitment device and monetary incentive for college students. The program, called CollegeBetter, is based off of a parimutuel betting market, where bets are placed together in a pool and payoff odds are calculated by sharing the pool among all winning bettors. With this program, students commit to their own academic performance by buying into a pool, where each pool has a predefined, common “commitment challenge”. These buy-ins are then collected into one pot of money for the pool. If a student achieves the pool’s commitment challenge, then the student splits the pot of money with other students who also achieved the commitment challenge. For example, a pool could be defined by the commitment challenge “raise your cumulative grade point average (GPA) by the end of the term.” Students then place parimutuel wagers on themselves to achieve this goal. Students who fail to raise their cumulative GPA do not recover their wager, while those who succeed get to split the pot of money.

From a series of surveys and field experiments conducted over a two-year period at a large public research university, this paper identifies characteristics of students who elected to use the program, and evaluates the impacts of the program on student outcomes. To address the first research question, I administered several surveys to undergraduates and provided instructions to complete an application to join the CollegeBetter pool for the term. Then, I contrasted the characteristics of students who completed the application against those who did not. To estimate the impacts of CollegeBetter on student outcomes, I randomly assigned students who completed the application to either join the CollegeBetter pool or to be completely excluded. Hence, I compared the outcomes of students who participated in CollegeBetter (i.e. treatment students) against those who wished to join but were randomly chosen to be excluded (i.e. control students).

Students who completed the application to join the program tended to be lower-achieving, overconfident, and self-identified procrastinators. Students randomly accepted to participate in the program (i.e. treatment students) were more likely to improve their cumulative GPA than students who applied for a spot to participate but were randomly excluded from the pool (i.e. control students). This treatment effect was primarily driven by students with the lowest cumulative GPAs entering the term. These results overall suggest a positive response to the program: Students with poorer prior academic performance were more likely to sign up for the program, and conditional on selection, the lowest achieving students were more likely to succeed.
